You have been given a Dockerized codebase for an unfinished 3D multiplayer Unity deck building rogue like. In its current status, the game consists of players playing two types of cards (Minions, cards that linger on the board with attack values, and Actions, usually one time use cards or cards with miscellaneous effects) on various Bases to deal damage to each other. Your task is to first, ensure that the online infrastructure that the code currently uses is secure enough to play on a small scale, peer-to-peer connection with friends, and modular enough that writing future mechanics to introduce to the game does not require editing or adding any major network/multiplayer code. 

After that, in the style of the other <Action>GA.cs and <Action>System.cs scripts, create new actions that players of the game would realistically need to be able to do. Immediate actions that certainly need to be implemented are DiscardCard, DestroyCard, ModifyCard, ActivateAbility, EditCard. Additionally, the current system for EndTurn should have a corresponding BeginTurn game action. All of these game actions should work with the architecture defined in ActionSystem.cs, meaning they can be activated successfully through the flow function, as well as added/removed as reactions from other Game Action instances. 

For any new game actions added, add a card to the JSON file with Card Data that has an ability that would make use of the new Game Action (this can be just in the description, it does not have to be properly implemented), this is for later testing purposes, so it should be a common use case for the new Game Action.

REQUIREMENTS: 
 - The current dependencies for online play should be used exclusively (Unity.Netcode), and the only dependencies that can be added to scripts should be non-networking dependencies.
 - The information distributed over the network should be reasonably secure, and light weight enough that two players can play from anywhere in the world (that does not require that much speed, as it is a turn based strategy game). 
 - New game actions must be as simple to implement for new mechanics of cards as possible, and should be able to be called or attached as a reaction with a maximum of three lines of code.
 - All new instances of game actions must be able to be referenced by other game actions, so if there are mechanics that need to attach themselves as reactions (e.g., if a player discards a card, there could be cards that have abilities that trigger on that condition, so the DiscardCardGA must be properly implemented and referenced in the scene.)

   - `AttachPerformer<T>` - Registers a performer for a GameAction type

   - `AddReaction(GameAction)` - Adds a reaction to the current action

   - **<Action>GA.cs** - Defines the GameAction with properties
